column2: Triggering yes will allow you access to many historical HQ, divisions and brigades of Japanese forces. Some will be given directly on map, others will be placed in the production queue.

Japan Southern Seas Campaign designed offensive operations against allied powers (United Kingdom, Netherlands, Autralia) that started in December 1941. Triggering this event will allow you getting HQ, brigades and support troops that were historicaly involved in these operations. As counterpart, you will suffer a temporary IC limitation and supply consumption increase.
So far, it seems that war is not going well for us... Ennemy forces have taken Iwo Jima and Okinawa and are now threatening our mainland! Let's mobilize some more troops to avoid the worst...
So far, it seems that war is not going well for us... Ennemy forces have taken Toyohara and Chongjin and are now threatening our mainland! Let's mobilize some more troops to avoid the worst....

It seems our last progresses against Japan have impressed their General Staff. The ennemy is raising dozens of fresh divisions to protect its mainland. Invading Japan could became a nightmare, even though these troops are mostly unequipped and untrained...

It seems our last progresses against Japan have impressed their General Staff. The ennemy is raising dozens of fresh divisions to protect its mainland. Invading Japan could became a nightmare, even though these troops are mostly unequipped and untrained...
Recall 24th Independant Mixed Brigade from Shanghai.

With tensions increasing on Soviet and Mongol borders, Japanese General Staff decide in April 1936 to remove 24th Independant Mixed Brigade from Shanghai to reinforce Kwantung army. By doing this, Japanese garrison in Shanghai was weakened.\n

The 2nd Shanghai incident, as known as "Battle of Shanghai" was the first major engagement fought between Republic of China and Empire of Japan at the beginning of the Second Sino-Japanese War and was one of the largest and bloodiest battles of the entire war. On August 9, an incident at the Hongqiao Airport heightened the tensions between the Chinese and Japanese forces in the Shanghai International Settlement. Japan began sending in reinforcements to Shanghai asking for a total withdraw of chinese forces in the area.

The 2nd Shanghai incident, as known as "Battle of Shanghai" was the first major engagement fought between Republic of China and Empire of Japan at the beginning of the Second Sino-Japanese War and was one of the largest and bloodiest battles of the entire war. On August 9, an incident at the Hongqiao Airport heightened the tensions between the Chinese and Japanese forces in the Shanghai International Settlement. Japan began sending in reinforcements to Shanghai asking for a total withdraw of chinese forces in the area.\n A fierce three-month battle occurred, involving more than 70 divisions (700,000 men) on the chinese side facing 9 japanese divisions supporte by planes, tanks, heavy artillery and ships from the 3rd Fleet, totalizing 300,000 men. Japan made amphibious landings on the beaches of the Yangtze River and Hangzhou Bay to support its isolated garrison in Shanghai.\nThe Chinese soldiers had to rely primarily on small-caliber weapons in their defense of Shanghai, against an overwhelming Japanese onslaught of air, naval, and armored striking power. In the end, Shanghai fell, and China lost a significant portion of its best troops, while also failing to elicit any international intervention.

Alongside Shanghai garrison made of SNLF and volunteers of the 3rd Japanese Fleet, 24th Independant Mixed Brigade is now available. It was a pretty good choice not to have withdrawn them in Manchuria!

Shanghai Expeditionary Force ('Shanhai haken gun') was a corps level force raised to relieve Japanese garrison in Shanghai besieged by Chinese troops. Led by general Iwane Matsui, this force was composed of 3rd and 11th Infantry Divisions and various support brigades, including tanks and heavy artillery.
Landings in the Shanghai area started on August 16th and Japanese troops rushed to help the encircled navy troops in the city.

§RNote for player: beware that 3rd and 11th Infantry Divisions will be removed from their current localisation to be sent in Shanghai.§B

On September 11th, more troops were assigned to Shanghai Expeditionary Force: 5th Heavy Artillery Brigade, 9th, 13th and the newly formed 101st Division.\n\n§RNote for player: beware that once again, these three divisions will be removed from their current localisation to be sent in Shanghai.§B

The China Expeditionary Army ('Shina hakengun') was an army group of the Imperial Japanese Army established in September 1939 from the merger of the Central China Expeditionary Army and Japanese Northern China Area Army, and was headquartered in city of Nanking. It was responsible for all Japanese military operations in China and reached over 1 million soldiers under its command at its peak.
Formation of the General Defense Command.

General Defense Command ('Boei Soshireibu') was an armygroup set up on July 1941 to command defense units in Japan mainland, Korea and Taïwan. The General Defense Command was also responsible for anti-aircraft defenses, and for organizing civil defense training.\nIts first commander was general Otozo Yamada. This HQ was dissolved on April 1945 in the perspective of an american invasion of Japan and replaced by 1st and 2nd General Armies.

Southern Expeditionary Army ('Nanpo gun') was set up in Saigon for japanese plans of expansion in South-East Asia, under command of general Hisaichi Terauchi.
4 different Army corps level forces were attached to this HQ:
14th Army designed to invade Philippines
15th Army designed to invade Burma
16th Army designed to invade Dutch East Indie
25th Army designed to invade Malaysia and attack Singapore.

1st and 2nd General Armies ('Dai-1 Sogun' and 'Dai-2 Sogun') were set up in April 1945 for the expected invasion of Japan by american troops. 1st General Army, based in Tokyo, was under command of general Hajime Sugiyama and was tasked to protect northern and eastern Honshu, including Tokyo area. 2nd General Army, based in Hiroshima, was under command of general Shunroku Hata and tasked to protect western Honshu, Kyushu and Shikoku.

Air General Army ('Koku Sogun') was formed in April 1945 to better coordinate Japan's air defenses in response to the mounting air offensive against Japan and the expected invasion of the country later that year. Japanese largly depleted airforces were placed under command of IJA general Masakazu Kawabe.
Formation of Northern China Area Army.

Northern China Area Army ('Kita Shina homen gun')was formed on August 21st, 1937 under the control of the Imperial General Headquarters. This Army level headquarters was responsible for direction and coordination of the Japanese military activity in all of north China and its first commander was count Hisaichi Terauchi. Units under its command rose from two Divisions (5th and 109th Divisions) to three armies (1st, 12th, 43rd)
Formation of Central China Expeditionary Army.

Central China Expeditionary Army ('Nakashina hakengun') was a field army of the Immperial Japanese Army set up the on February 14, 1938 under command of general Shunroku Hata, by combining Shanghai Expeditionary Force and the IJA Tenth Army.
Formation of Southern China Area Army and 22nd Army.

Japanese South China Area Army ('Minami Shina homen gun') was a field army of the Imperial Japanese Army formed on February 9, 1940 under the control of the China Expeditionary Army. Its first commander was general Rikichi Ando. Headquartered in Canton, it was responsible for direction of the Japanese invasion of southern China, garrisoning Japanese-occupied Guangdong Province and controlling military operations in neighboring Guangxi Province.\nThe Twenty-Second Army ('Dai-nijyuni gun') was formed the same day, put under Southern china area army command and served as a garrison force for the southern Chinese province of Guangxi. It notably participate to the invasion of French Indochina.
Formation of 1st and 2nd Area Armies in Manchukuo.

Japanese First Area Army ('Dai-ichi homen gun') was a field army, formed on July 4, 1942 under the control of the Kwantung Army as a military reserve and garrison force to maintain security and public order in northern Manchukuo. Its first commander was general Tomoyuki Yamashita. Consisting mostly of minimally-trained reservists, conscripted students and home guard militia, without adequate weapons or supplies, units of the 1st Area Army proved to be no match for the Red Army when the Soviet Union invaded Manchukuo at the end of World War II.\n\nJapanese Second Area Army ('Dai-ni homen gun') was a field army of the Imperial Japanese Army also formed on July 4, 1942 in Manchuria. Its first commander was Korechika Anami. 2nd Area Army was transferred to the Davao in the Philippines in late 1943, and tasked with defending western New Guinea and the eastern part of the occupied Netherlands East Indies.
Formation of 3rd Area Army in Southern Manchukuo.

Japanese Third Area Army ('Dai san homen gun') was a field army activated in October 29, 1943 under the command of general Naozaburo Okabe and headquartered in Mukden (Manchuria). Like the 1st Area Army, it was a military reserve and garrison force to maintain security and public order in southern Manchukuo as many veteran divisions of the Kwantung Army were transferred to the various southern fronts in the Pacific War. Most of its units were shattered in a desesperate counterattack against the Red Army in August 1945 along the MukdenPort Arthur railway.\n\nMany surviving soldiers of the 3rd Area Army, including General Ushiroku, became prisoners in Siberia and other parts of the Soviet Union after the surrender of Japan.

Japanese Fifth Area Army ('Dai-go homen gun')was a field army activated in March 16, 1944, under command of general Kiishiro Higuchi, to secure the border between Japan and Soviet Union (Karafuto/Soviet Sakhalin, Chishima Islands/Kuriles). It was headquartered in Sapporo. Like other japanese formations in 1945, this army was lacking weapons and ammunition and could not do anything but delaying soviet forces advance in August 1945.

Japanese Sixth Area Army ('Dai roku homen gun') was a field army formed on August 25, 1944 under the China Expeditionary Army primarily as a military reserve and garrison force for the occupation of the central provinces of China between the Yangtze River and the Yellow River. Its first commander was general Yasuji Okamura.

Japanese Seventh Area Army ('Dai nana homen gun') was a field army formed on March 19, 1944 and based in Japanese-occupied Malaya, Singapore and Borneo, Java, and Sumatra to consolidate a new defense line after the loss of the Solomon Islands, New Guinea and eastern portions of the Netherlands East Indies. It had its headquarters at Singapore. Its first commander was general Kenji Doihara and units initially assigned to the Area Army were the 16th, 25th and 29th Armies..

Japanese Eighth Area Army ('Dai-hachi homen gun') was a field army formed on November 16, 1942 under the Southern Expeditionary Army Group for the specific task of opposing landings by Allied forces in Japanese-occupied Solomon Islands and New Guinea. It had its headquarters at Rabaul, New Britain and saw considerable combat in the Solomon Islands campaign, Bougainville campaign and New Guinea campaign. Its first commander was general Hitoshi Imamura..

Japanese Tenth Area Army ('Dai-ju homen-gun') was a field army formed out of the Taiwan Army of Japan on September 29, 1944 as part of the last desperate defense effort by the Empire of Japan to deter possible landings of Allied forces in Taiwan. It was headquartered in Taipei and consisted of the 32nd army, 40th army, and other smaller units, under command of general Rikichi Ando.

Japanese Eleventh Area Army ('Dai jyuichi homen gun') was a field army formed on February 6, 1945 and was part of the last desperate defense effort by the Empire of Japan to deter possible landings of Allied forces in central Honshu. The Japanese 11th Area Army was responsible for the Tohoku region of Japan and was headquartered in Sendai, Miyagi. Its commander was general Teiichi Yoshimoto.

Japanese Twelfth Area Army ('Dai-juni homen gun') was a field army formed on February 2, 1945 under the First General Army as part of the last desperate defense effort by the Empire of Japan to deter possible landings of Allied forces in central Honshu. This Army headquartered in Tokyo and under command of general Keisuke Fujie was responsible for the Kanto region of Japan.

Japanese Thirteenth Area Army ('Dai-jyuhachi homen gun') was a field army formed on February 1st, 1945 under the Japanese First General Army in the later stages of the war. It was responsible for the Tokai region of Japan and was headquartered in Nagoya, under command of general Tasuku Okada.

Fourteenth Area Army ('Dai-jyuyon homen gun') was a field army formed in the Philippines on July 28, 1944, when Allied landings were considered imminent. The Fourteenth Area Army was formed by reinforcing and renaming the Japanese Fourteenth Army ('Dai-jyuyon gun') who was a smaller, corps-level formation. It was initially placed under general Masaharu Homma's command.

Fifteenth Area Army ('Dai jyugo homen gun')was a field army formed on February 1, 1945 as part of the last desperate defense effort by the Empire of Japan to deter possible landings of Allied forces in central Honshu. It was initially placed under general Masakazu Kawabe's command.

Sixteenth Area Army ('Dai jyuroku homen gun') was a field army formed on February 1, 1945 as part of the last desperate defense effort by the Empire of Japan to deter possible landings of Allied forces in Kyushu during Operation Downfall. The Army was headquartered in what is now part of Chikushino city, Fukuoka Prefecture and under command of general Isamu Yokoyama. By the time of the Japanese surrender, the 16th Area Army had 916,828 personnel on Kyushu either in position or in various stages of deployment.

Seventeenth Area Army ('Dai-junana homen gun') was a field army formed on January 22, 1945 as the successor to the Chosen Army of Japan as part of the last desperate defense effort by the Empire of Japan to deter possible landings of Allied forces on the Korean peninsula. It was headquartered in Keijo under the command of general Seishiro Itagaki. However, the actual administrative structure of the former Chosen Army remained in place, and thus the leadership of the 17th Area Army concurrently held the equivalent posts within the Chosen Army, which was also called the Korean District Army.\n17th Area Army was thus demobilized without having seen combat, and units remained armed and in their garrisons until United States Army forces arrived in Korea.

Eighteenth Area Army ('Dai jyuhachi homen gun') was a field army formed on January 4, 1943 as the Siam Garrison Command ('Tai-koku Chutongun shirebu'). It was renamed the Japanese Thirty-ninth Army on December 14, 1944 and became the 18th Area Army on July 7, 1945, shortly before the end of the Pacific War.\nThe 18th Area Army was under the control of the Southern Expeditionary Army Group as a military reserve and garrison force, ostensibly to help defend the Empire of Japan's nominal ally, the Empire of Siam against possible invasion by the Allies, but in more practical terms, it was present to ensure that Siam remained an ally to Japan. It was headquartered in Bangkok, under command of general Aketo Nakamura.

Burma Area Army ('Biruma homen gun') was a field army formed on 27 March 1943, under the control of the Southern Expeditionary Army Group as a garrison force to defend the nominally-independent State of Burma against liberation by British forces based in neighboring India. Its commander was general Masakazu Kawabe.\nThis Army was not equipped as other nominal units of comparable strength due to the dwindling external supply situation mainly because of increasing US and UK attacks on the Japanese naval supply lanes. In 1943 the main responsibility of the BAA was to quell insurgencies of the Shan, Karen, and other tribal groups in the remote regions, and react to incursions of the Chindits from British India or Kuomintang forces from Yunnan.\nThe surviving remnants of the Japanese Burma Area Army surrendered to the Allied forces at Moulmein on 15 August 1945.

Initially raised during the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), Japanese 1st Army ( 'Dai-ichi gun', nicknamed 'Otsu') was raised again on 26 August 1937 in Tianjin. As all japanese armies, it was a corps-size unit, attached to the China Garrison Army and later to the newly formed Japanese Northern China Area Army.Its commander was general Kiyoshi Katsuki\n\n2nd Japanese Army ('Dai-ni gun', nicknamed 'Ikio', meaning 'Vigorous') was also raised again in August 1937 and placed under command of general Toshizo Nishio. This corps was assigned to various commands: Japanese Northern China Army (1937-1938), Japanese First and Second Area Armies in Manchukuo (1942-1945) before being transfered to the Southern Expeditionnary Army Group in the Celebes at the end of war.

Formed during the Russo-Japanese war (1905), Japanese 3rd Army ('Dai-san gun', nicknamed 'Iwa' meaning 'Rock') was raised again in January 1938 and placed under command of general Otozo Yamada. It was set up as a garrison force designed to protect the border against Soviet Union.\nAs its best divisions were assigned to other theaters during the later stages of war, Japanese 3rd Army was not match for the experienced battle-hardened Soviet Army in 1945, and it was forced back to the Korean border were it surrendered.

Also existing during Russo-Japanese War, Japanese 4th Army ('Dai-yon gun', nicknamed 'Hikari' meaning 'Light')was raised again in July 1938 as a garrison force to guard the northern borders of Manchukuo.\nIts first commander was general Kesago Nakajima.

Like 3rd and 4th Armies, Japanese 5th Army ('Dai-go gun', nicknamed 'Joshudan' meaning 'Castle') was raised again on December 7, 1937 in Manchukuo as a garrison force to guard the eastern borders against possible incursions by the Soviet Red Army.\nIts first commander was general Motoo Furusho.

Japanese 6th Army ('Dai-roku gun', nicknamed 'Mamoru', meaning 'Protect') was initially raised on August 4, 1939 in Hailar, Manchukuo as a garrison force to guard the western borders against possible incursions by the Soviet Red Army. It was a major participant in the Nomonhan Incident/Battle of Khalkhin Gol, during which time it took severe casualties.\nIts first commander was general Rippei Ogitsu.
Formation of Army of the Tokyo Bay.

Army of Tokyo Bay ('Tokyo wan heidan') was an army formed 19 June 1945, under the 12th area army as part of the last desperate defense effort to protect Japan against allied landings. Based in Tateyama, this army was in command of 354th Division, 96th and 114th Independent Mixed Brigades and Tokyo Bay Fortress Brigade. It consisted mostly of poorly trained reservists, conscripted students and Volunteer Fighting Corps home guard militia. It was demobilized at the surrender of Japan on August 15, 1945, without having seen combat.
Punish 1st Infantry Division 'Jade' for its participation in the 2-2-6 Coup.

After the 2-2-6 coup, 1st Infantry Division was punished and sent for garrison duties in Manchukuo. Its cavalry brigade (2nd) remained in Japanese mainland.\nThis division fought soviet gunboats during Kanchazu incident (June 1937), elements were also involved in the Nonomhan Incident (battle of Khalkin Gol - 1939).\nDivision was transfered to Philippines in 1944.
Imperial Japanese Headquarters decide to take further mesures toward war footing.
Summer plans for massive expansion of infantry divisions.
Our summer divisions are ready - 3 more divisions.
Formation of new divisions after the fall of Okinawa.

Following the escalation of hostilities in Shanghai in August 1937, the Navy organized additional SNLF battalions, which were often organized for a specific task and then disbanded.\nIn addition to the Shanghai SNLF, three other SNLF from this period remained active throughout the war. These were the Sasebo 8th SNLF, Yokosuka 4th SNLF and Maizuru 1st SNLF. These three SNLF were large but relatively lightly armed, and they remained on Hainan on garrison duty throughout the war..
Formation of Independent Mixed Brigades for garrison duties in China.
Formation of Border Garrisons in Manchukuo.
Formation of Karafuto Independent Mixed Brigade.
New Brigades for garrison duties in China.

In november 1939, Japan raised another 10 IMB for garrison duties in China. 11th and 18th Independent Mixed Brigades will be placed in the production queue but you'll have to build the other brigades by yourself.
New Border Garrisons units for Manchukuo.
5 new garrisons divisions were raised in Manchukuo in March 1940 and were attached to 4th, 5th and 20th Armies.

South Seas Detachment - Nankai Shitai was a brigade-size force of the Imperial Japanese Army  designed in 1941 to seize Wake, Guam and the Gilberts. As part of the South Seas Force, it fell under command of the Imperial Japanese Navy. It later rejoined the 55th Division for the New Guinea Campaign.
Send support brigades for Kwantung army.
From July 11th to August 8th, no less than 17 artillery regiments, 17 anti-aircraft regiments, 5 anti-tank battalions and 2 tank regiments were sent in Manchuria.

The Tauran Incident was a border clash between Soviet Union and Japan and their respective puppet states of Mongolia and Manchukuo that happened in March 1936.\nA force of 100 Mongol soldiers with 6 Soviet advisors took control of the contested village of Tauran on March, 11th. Imperial Japan Army mounted a successful counterattack, supported by light tanks, armored cars and warplanes, that overwelmed Mongol defenders who were forced to retreat leaving 59 killed...

Manchukuo Imperial Army, armed force of the Japanese State of Manchukuo made a large use of cavalry brigades to secure its territory, for border duties and local unrests repression.
Typical Manchurian cavalry brigade was composed of a headquarters, three cavalry regiments, and an artillery company, for a total of 1,500 men and 1,500 horses.

§RHere you can receive a whole Manchukuo Cavalry Corps as an expeditionnary force...§B

In 1937, Imperial General Staff started to move troops to reinforce North China army for an upcoming confrontation with China.
20th Infantry Division was called from Korea, 2nd Independant Mixed Brigade from Kwantung Army, 5th, 6th, 10th Infantry Division from Japanese Mainland. This was also including 1st Tank Regiment (Colonel Baba) and 2nd Tank Regiment (Colonel Imada) from Kurume and Chiba.

§RNote for player: You'll have to ship troops manually to Manchuria.§B

The Kanchazu Island Incident took place in late June 1937 between Japanese and Soviet forces on the Amur river. Soviet forces from the Amur Flotilla started to unload troops on the Kanchazu Island located in the center of the river, crossing the official frontier between Manchukuo and Soviet Union. Japan reacted quickly and mounted a counterattack with its 1st Infantry Division.  49th Infantry regiment led by Colonel Mihara Kanae inflicted substancial losses, including destruction of a Type 1124 BKA gunboat  by combination of machinegun and 37 mm At guns fire. Soviet forces were forced to withdraw and on June 29th, japanese ambassador Shigemistu Mamoru met foreign Minister Maxim Litvinov who accepted that the island would remain to Manchukuo. Apparently, the Soviets were more concerned with events unfolding in North China and Europe, as well as internal strife.

The 1938 Yellow River Flood was a flood created by Nationalist Government in Central China in an attempt to slow down Japanese advance in China. Dykes on the Yellow river were opened near Huayuankou on early June 1938 and floods covered and destroyed thousands of square kilometers of farmland. Casualties were heavy with 400,000 to 500,000 dead and 3 million refugees. Strategic value of the flood has been questionned as it didnt stop Japanese advance towards Wuhan. It also produce a long term psychological effect on the Chinese population:  large parts of people blamed the KMT for being responsible of the losses and turned themselves to Japanese or Communist Chinese...\n\n§RNote for player: due to this flooding, you will suffer penalties in combat and speed in the area between Zengzhou, Hefei and Jinhu (North of Nanjing) for monthes.§B
Japan starts to reinforce Kwantung Army after Barbarossa.

On July 1941, war between Germany and Soviet Union pushed Japanese High Command to start reinforcing Kwantung Army. A weakened Soviet Union could be an intersting target.\nJapanese forces in the area were enlarge from 400.000 to 700.000 men with new units - 3rd Cavalry Division, 51st and 57th Infantry Divisions  and new tank and artillery brigades to strengthen already existing units.
Protect our country from air raids.

After Doolittle air raid in April 1942, Japan started being concerned about allied bombings raids. Japanese mainland AA units were equipped with around 150 anti-aircraft guns, most of which were obsolete, and its personnel were poorly trained. In November 1942, a significant effort was decided to reach a total of 20 Air regiments.\nIt's up to you to decide if you need some more anti-aicraft units.

Tainan Naval Air Group (Tainan Kaigun Kokutai) was an elite fighter unit of the Imperial Japanese Navy that spawned more aces than any other Japanese unit during WW2. It was deployed in March 1942 in Rabaul (New Britain) and Lae (New Guinea) as a part of IJN 11th Air Fleet. Tainan Naval Air Group fought New Guinea and Guadalcanal campaigns, destroying many allied aircrafts. This unit was well known by allied forces who rapidly identify three Japanese Aces as the 'Cleanup Trio':\nHiroyoshi Nishizawa, aka 'Demon of Rabaul',Toshio Ota and Saburo Sakai.\n.

In April 1943, Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander of the Imperial Japanese Navy, scheduled an inspection tour of the Solomon Islands and New Guinea. He planned to inspect Japanese air units participating in Operation I-Go that had begun on April 7th. In addition, the tour would boost Japanese morale following the disastrous Guadalcanal Campaign and its subsequent evacuation during January and February.Staff officers made several warnings about risks taken by the IJN commander in chief...

In April 1943, Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander of the Imperial Japanese Navy, scheduled an inspection tour of the Solomon Islands and New Guinea. He planned to inspect Japanese air units participating in Operation I-Go that had begun on April 7th. In addition, the tour would boost Japanese morale following the disastrous Guadalcanal Campaign and its subsequent evacuation during January and February.\nUS intelligence and Navy cryptographers deciphered Japanese communications and discovered that Yamamoto will personally fly to Bougainville. American high command took this opportunity to get rid of admiral Yamamoto and Admiral Chester W. Nimitz ordered an interception on April 17th that would be called 'Operation Vengeance'.

Admiral Yamamoto decided to begin his tour flying with his staff in 2 medium bombers covered by 6 navy fighters from Rabaul to Balalae Airfield, on a island near Bougainville in the Solomon Islands. Depart was schedule on April 18th at 6:00, ignoring warnings of officiers thinking that this kind of frontline flight was too risky.\nYamamoto also ignored that US military intelligence had intercepted and decrypted japanese communications in the area...

10 minutes before landing at Balalae, Admiral Yamamotos flight was ambushed by american P-38s. Its aircraft  a G4M 'Betty' - was shot down and crashed in the jungle, 14 km from the town of Panguna. Vice-admiral Matome Ugaki escape death by crash-landing in the water. A total of 19 japanese pilos and superior officers were killed during the ambush.
Japanese opinion was told about Yamamotos death nearly one month later and its ashes return to Japan at Kisarazu aboard battleship Musashi on May 23rd, 1943.

The 'Navy ko incident' - japanese name for Yamamotos killing   delivered a severe blow to Japanes forces moral and organization and a certain boost to USAs ones...

Led by Captain Thomas G. Lanphier Jr, a 18 P-38s flight took of on April 18th from Kukum Field on Guadalcanal island and made an indirect approach to avoid Japanese detection. At 9:34, american fighter met Yamamotos flight and shot down its G4M 'Betty'. Part of Yamomotos staff that was on the second bomber  including vice admiral Matome Ugaki  escape death by crash-landing in the water.
A Controversy began later about who shot down the admirals aircraft as both Captain Lanphier et Lieutnant Rex T. Barber claimed the kill...

Operation Vengeance delivered a severe blow to Japanes forces moral and organization.

PETA  'Pembela Tanah Air' or 'Defenders of the Homeland' - was an Indonesian volunteers militia raised by Japan in late 1943 to protect occupied Indonesia from possible allied landings. Up to 69 battalions were raised, mostly in Java (37,000 men) and Sumatra (20,000 men). This force was disbanded on August 17th, 1945 by Japanese order..

The Shanghai Incident, also called January 28 incident, was a conflict between Empire of Japan and Republic of China in the Shanghai International Settlement that happened in 1932.\nJapanese aggressivness in China provoked anti-japanese demonstrations in Shanghai, including the beating and killing of a buddist monk. Japanese navy and army forces overreacted and the conflict degenerated into heavy fight, involving more than 100.000 men, 80 ships and 300 planes facing the 50.000 chinese soldiers of 5th Army and 19th Route Army.\nOn May 5, China and Japan signed the Shanghai Ceasefire Agreement that made Shanghai a demilitarized zone and forbade China to garrison troops while allowing the presence of a few Japanese units in the city. China was allowed to keep only a small police force within the city.
